com.github.jonathanxd.iutils.box

Interface BaseBox<T>

  • All Superinterfaces:
    java.lang.Comparable<BaseBox<T>>, UnknownBox<T>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    IMutableBox<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    ImmutableBox, MutableBox

    public interface BaseBox<T>
extends java.lang.Comparable<BaseBox<T>>, UnknownBox<T>
    Box is a value holder, boxes are commonly used to modify variables from different scopes (or methods), example: 
     
 int x = 0;
 Consumer<Integer> consumer = (i) -> {
     x += 1;
 };
    The value X needs to be "Local variable x defined in an enclosing scope must be final or effectively final"
    A way to solve this is using Box, see example using MutableBox 
     
 final MutableBox<String> x = MutableBox.of("Hey");
 Consumer<Integer> consumer = (i) -> {
     x.set("Hi");
 };
    For primitive types you can also use IntBox (or other variants). 
     
 final IntBox x = new IntBox(0);
 Consumer<Integer> consumer = (i) -> {
     x.add();
 };
    Box shares the same logic and code, but does not have HistoryContainer, this will probably replace the old container.
